text: [Music]
Welcome to Raging Moderates. I'm Jessica
Tarlov. Today I'm joined by former
Republican Congressman Charlie Dent. He
is a lifelong conservative who broke
with his party to support Joe Biden in
2020 and then Kla Harris in 2024, making
him one of the few Republicans willing
to say enough to Donald Trump's grip on
the GOP. These days, he's the executive
director of the Aspen Institute's
congressional program where he's focused
on fostering real bipartisan dialogue in
Congress. He's been vocal about the need
for a reckoning within his party and is
working to steer the conversation back
to responsible governance, trust, and
civility. Congressman Dent, welcome to
the show. Hey, Jessica, great to be with
you. Thank you. Yeah. No, thank you for
joining us. Um, I'm excited to talk to
you. You're brave soldiers. You uh never
Trumpers who actually come over and
support the other side. And that's where
I want to begin our conversation. So,
you backed Biden in 2020, Kla Harris in
uh what ultimately pushed you to cross
the aisle in both elections? Was it
Trump? How he redefined the Republican
party? Can you talk us through your
journey? For me, look, I if you you
called me a conservative. I some people
would call me center right, you know,
common sense conservative. I mean,
moderate, pragmatic, choose your choose
your favorite term. But what drove me uh
away was uh you know I always said this
wasn't these these elections with Donald
Trump were not about right or left from
a policy perspective. I always thought
they're about right or wrong. I often
thought that what the MAGA movement
represented in the form of Donald Trump
uh was a was a a particular type of
protectionism,
isolationism,
nivism, at times
nihilism and what I would call a a
dangerous populism and and it really is
not particularly ideological really
about loyalty to a particular
individual. It's not about fidelity to
any type of uh principles. If you were
to ask me what kind of person, you know,
I kind of view myself as an Edmund Burke
type that we're going to be a
Republicans that we should be about
incremental change and we believe in
evolutionary systems, not revolutionary
systems. We believe in in measured
statements, temperance, we believe in,
you know, discipline. Uh and and that's
kind of where we kind stability and
order. I mean, that's where I think a
lot of sort of center-right folks come
from or center right conservatives come
from. And I don't think that's where the
party is right now. It's taken on a form
of radical positions like on tariffs
that are completely antithetical
uh to free markets uh and certainly
represent a type of of revolutionary
change that should really uh appall
people who would kind of embrace that
centerright or conservative ideology.
Yeah. I mean, you're from Pennsylvania
represented there. You have someone like
a Crystal Delusio
um who talks a bit of a protectionist
game, not nearly like what Trump is
talking about, but you have a Bernie
Sanders as well. Federman has dabbled in
this too. How do you feel like the
difference between the kind of positions
that they're supporting when you say we
have to protect American manufacturing
and American workers versus how Trump is
implementing this tariff plan? can be
better explained to the American people.
Well, well, Trump's tariff policy is
essentially very similar to what the AFL
CIO would be proposing. The AFL CIO,
Democrat, Sean Feain at the UAW, is very
supportive of many of these tariffs
apparently. And I guess what I find
remarkable is that Democrats have not
been able to articulate a a strong
forceful opposition to the Trump tariffs
because many of them agree with the
basic policy. They might not like the
way Trump is doing it, but for years,
you know, I' I've been in politics. I'
I've heard plenty of Democrats from
Bernie Sanders and others who've
embraced this idea of protectionism in a
very naked form. And that's what I guess
disturbs me most about where my party
is, is that, and we were not that party.
We were the party that was embracing
opening markets for American producers.
We had a a forward-looking aspirational
view of the world uh that we could
actually compete. and and many of those
who were advocating this type of
protectionism have thrown up their hands
and said, "Boy, you know, we're just not
good enough anymore." And you know,
look, I'm all for using tariffs and
counterveailing duties on a very
targeted basis, but in response to
problems, you know, illegal dumping or
illegal subsidies, certainly people uh
countries that are using uh child labor
uh and other forms of what we would
consider to be real trade abuses or in
the case of China where they they coers
technology transfers, which is a big
problem, or steel int steel intellectual
property. Okay, that's how you use them.
But we don't use these across the board
tariffs against friend and foe alike and
think that this is somehow going to grow
our economy. It'll just have the
opposite effect. It'll be very negative
and and it'll punish uh American
consumers as well as manufacturers and
farmers. Pretty self-evident to me. And
just look at how the markets have
reacted. Uh if we need any further
explanation, but you're seeing it all
across the country, people are reacting.
Just the other day in the Allentown
Morning Call, Matt Trucks uh said
they're laying off 250 to 350 employees
largely over the tariffs. I mean, this
is what we're dealing with. So,
everything you just said is true. He has
the lowest approval rating in 70 years.
Underwater on every issue. Still, you
know, does well on border security,
which kudos to you. He's basically shut
down the border, which is something that
we desperately needed to happen. It
feels like people can disapprove of him
and it still doesn't transfer over to
turning on him. And this is not just the
MAGA base. Like CNN did polling that
showed if the election were, you know,
held today, who do you think would do a
better job managing this? And he still
edged out Kla Harris. And what do you
think that is that doesn't allow people
to transfer over to the other side to
just say actually I I don't think he
could do this job. Democratic approval
ratings are in the in the tank as well.
I mean their numbers are not very good.
Many people I saw a poll recently
suggesting about 70% of voters thought
they were out of out of touch uh with
the American public. At the end of the
day, what I I do think motivates those
voters who would prove decisive in a
presidential election. These are the
voters who are not firmly in the Trump
camp or firmly in the Democratic or Kla
Harris camp. These are people who are
persuadable and it's quite clear to me
that many of them were motivated by
economic issues. To the extent that we
are having this debate about, you know,
where Trump said he was going to lower
prices on day one uh and here we are you
know going into a trade war that is
having real world impacts on people's
401ks. They're worried about their jobs.
uh you know a recession is seems
probable at this point. Uh and I think
economic issues will drive the day and
of course you know what we're hearing
this isn't none of this policy is
lowering prices. So even though the
president is I think largely in step
with where the American people are on
border security where they clearly want
the border uh controlled they might not
like the way Trump does things. Um I
think they I think at the end of the day
the uh these economic issues are going
to motivate uh those uh those other uh
what I'll call swing voters what's left
of them. Uh and you know remember too I
also looked at some polling recently too
you know on this 100 day anniversary
there must have been a dozen polls and
some kind of pulled out. I try not to
talk about polls too often but they all
came out and it showed the generic
congressional ballot I think was about
minus 7 for the Republicans. So, I mean,
in other words, they were the Democrats
were doing better there. And remember,
midterm elections are usually not about
the party out of power, even though
Democrats are viewed very unfavorably.
Luckily for them, the election is not
going to be about them. It's going to be
about Donald Trump and the Republican
party. That's how midterms typically go.
History will be on our side for that.
But, uh, you're still fearful or I'm
still fearful and can't believe that
we're only, you know, 110 days in,
whatever it is at this point. What do
you say to Republicans who feel
similarly to you but can't bring
themselves to take the box for a
Democrat? Well, what I tell them, you
know, you vote vote your values. And I
said, here, you know, here's my values
as a Republican. I do think we should be
about uh a strong national defense or
peace through strength. And that means
you embrace your allies. You don't
embrace autocrats like Vladimir Putin
and Kim Jong-un. Why why would we do
this? or uh you know and we and so
that's that's one issue. We should
embrace economic freedom as a party uh
that you know we should be uh you know
vigorously opposed to these types of
indiscriminate across the board tariffs.
I mean that's what we should be you know
we should be for certain things and
against certain things. I mean so we
need to articulate this. We should be
for the constitution um that we believe
in the rule of law. That's our that's
these are fundamentally Republican and
conservative principles. We should be
about the union, trying to keep it
together. Our founder was Abraham
Lincoln. That's what he was about and
what why our party was born to maintain
this union as big and diverse as it is
and as as challenging as it can be. Uh
so these are just a few core principles
that I think we need to uh continue to
beat on. And in fact, I'm part of an
organization called our our Republican
Legacy where we have articulated many of
these principles where we are trying to
uh talk to Republicans about, you know,
embracing real real principles, not
about simply adopting whatever it is
that the that the president wants. is
the expectation that the Republican
party can go back to what it once was
after Trump because they I mean he did
tell Kristen Walker that he's not
thinking about a third term. Steve
Bannon has other ideas about that. We're
not here to kind of debate whether he's
going to do that or not, but it's a big
open question what the party looks like
post Trump. Yeah. I I don't think the
party I don't believe the party goes
back to where it was. But at the same
time, some of those principles I just
laid out are enduring principles.
They're the ones that have sustained the
party since Abraham Lincoln. Uh and so I
think that we should focus on those core
principles. Once again, like I said, we
should be talking about peace through
strength. We should be talking about
embracing allies. We should be talking
about the Constitution, uh the Union, uh
you know, economic freedom. a lot of
people who are Trump voters who aren't
real happy with everything he says and
does and may disagree with him. They're
voting for uh Trump because they so much
dislike where the Democrats are on many
policy issues. So, I think that's really
where we need leadership in the party to
to to present a
counternarrative. Quite often, you know,
you hear the MAGA narrative and and
where I've been critical of some of my
former congressional Republican
colleagues is they've been too quiet. uh
that you know you cannot counter that
MAGA narrative with silence. Nothing
there to to counter MAGA's argument.
Well then MAGA's going to win every
single time. But I think because of this
trade war um there's a tremendous
opening uh for a lot of Republicans to
counter. And remember too, Donald
Trump's not ever going to be on the
ballot again. At least not not legally
or constitutionally. He's not going to
be on the ballot again. And so he's a
lame duck president and Republicans will
be up in 2026 and many of them are going
to need separation from Donald Trump and
now is the time to start making
arguments about, you know, how they are
different than the president. Uh
particularly those who are in those
marginal and swing districts who hope to
survive. You know, they're not going to
be able to run simply embracing Donald
Trump whose approval rating is what
around 40 now, the low 40s. That's not a
way you're going to win an election. So,
I think there's an opportunity now for
Republicans to start speaking up. Yeah.
When you look at what the reconciliation
bill will have in it and those huge cuts
to Medicaid and you mentioned swing
district Republicans who in most cases
have hundreds of thousands of more
people in their districts on Medicaid
than the margins that they want. You
think this is going to be an obvious
one, but time and again, something that
Trump does or Trump allies do scares
people to the point that they feel like
they can't even represent their
constituents. Well, you remember what
happened during Trump won on let's take
the Medicaid issue. And you know, at
that point, reconciliation was being
used to repeal and replace uh Obamacare
or the Affordable Care Act. And and I
was one of the folks who, you know, rang
the bell on the Medicaid issue at the
time because that, you remember what the
debate was then? Many states like mine
had expanded Medicaid. Basically, we
would have ended up dumping, you know,
all sorts of millions of people back
onto the market with an insufficient tax
credit. They would have lost coverage.
And I just said, "This is not
acceptable." And I was making arguments
on behalf of various Republican
governors, four of whom asked me to
present Donald Trump with a letter about
this issue, which I did uh directly. Um,
and what was that like? Uh well, I had
two meetings with him actually. One in
the Oval Office where I gave him the
letter. He was respectful. He listened
and I told him my concerns with the bill
and that meeting ended fine. That was on
Tuesday. Thursday I got invited back and
it was a smackdown meeting. You know
why, you know, basically in front of a
whole bunch of people I told him I
wouldn't vote for the bill and he and I
was against it and he was, you know, he
took it well the first time. It was the
second and third time he went crazy. Um
told me I was going to destroy the
Republican party. I'm blaming you,
Charlie. It's your fault. you know, I
might as well just go to parades. I'll
go cut ribbons. I'm blaming you. Taxes
are done. It's all over. You're being
very selfish. You know, he's going off
on me. That's a pretty good imitation.
Yeah. Yeah. I know. But then he says, it
got really interesting. Then he says to
me, then I finally have as he's berating
me, you know, like why I'm not voting
for the bill. And I told him why. And he
because he basically had me back in on a
Thursday. And I there were 17 members of
Congress around the table in the cabinet
room. And he said to me, I was the
second one he called on and that's how I
was voting. And I said, "I'm against the
bill. I'm going to vote against it." And
then, you know, then he said, "Well,
why?" And I said, "Well, for the same
reasons I told you on Tuesday, you know,
it's Thursday and nothing's really
changed." Uh, and so and so, um, and so,
but bottom line is after he got done,
you know, trying to berate me or trying
to bully me, I said to, "Mr. President,
can I ask you a question?" He said,
"Yeah." And I said, "Are you telling
me?" Because he kept saying, "Taxes are
done. Taxes are done." You remember at
that time they were trying to do tax
reform. And uh and I and and I said,
"Are you telling me, Mr. president that
if we don't pass this this uh healthc
care bill in this particular form, he
won't be able to do tax reform because
the tax baseline is not going to be low
enough. That's exactly right. And when
you lose, you lose. He goes off again,
blah blah blah blah blah, you know, same
stuff repeating himself. And it kind of
got nasty. And then um and then after
about a long time of this, they were
going back and forth a little bit. And
finally it ends and it was this is all
picked up in one of the tell all books,
Team of Vipers, for about three pages. I
didn't know that until the book was
written. didn't even know anybody was
taking notes recording. Someone is
always taking notes. Someone is there
and Cliff Sims who worked for him who
wrote the book, he did it nevertheless.
So basically it all breaks, you know. So
we get he gets done with his tirade. I
had asked him my questions and and then
we just sat there staring at each other.
You real awkward silence, you know, that
uh that I forgot about but they
recounted in the book. And then he said,
"Yeah, Trump realized at that moment
that wasn't budging." So then Trump goes
around the whole room, asks everybody
how they're voting. Yes. Lean. Yes. That
took a while. And then um and then one
of the guys and I now a couple of them
lied to him. Uh but um that's but that's
to be expected. And so after it's all
over after 45 minutes of all this going
around the room and you know
chitchatting about other things, he he
turns back at me and he says, "You still
a hard no?" I said, "Yeah, I'm still a
no, Mr. President." Well, he goes off
again. Now I was really getting annoyed
at this point. I finally I waited like
five or 10 seconds. I said, "Oh, come
on, Mr. President." He said, "Oh, I'm
done talking to you. I don't want to
hear tell them turns away like that.
Looks in the other direction. The
meeting breaks up. I just look at Mike
Pence and say, "Mike, you know, this
isn't helping anything." And and then
one of the one of the young aids came up
to me and who I I know. And he'd worked
in the house and he said, "Hey, Mr.
Dent, Mr. Dent, why don't you go up to
the president privately now as the
meeting's breaking up that just tell him
to vote for the bill?" And um and I know
what his motivation was. He Mark Meadows
and Jim Jordan at that particular moment
weren't for the bill either. Uh, and uh,
I think he wanted them to I think he
wanted Trump to blame Meadows and
Jordan, but I said, "Hey, I said to this
young guy, hey, you know what? I came
here and no, I'm an F no now." Okay. So,
I'm going to spend the next 24 hours
find another four or five Republicans to
vote against this piece of crap of a
bill. Uh, and so the next day they had
to pull the bill off the floor. We got a
couple guys to vote against it. And so
that was in March of 2017. So, the point
I'm making is Medicaid was a tough issue
then. It's a tougher issue now. Yeah. uh
you know because so many more
Republicans now recognize that much of
their base is on Medicaid. And so I
think you know if we couldn't reform
Medicaid the way they wanted to then why
do we think you'll be able to do it now?
I mean it's I mean they might try to
stick a work requirement in there. Uh
but uh beyond that I not not seeing how
they're going to do too many significant
changes particularly in the US Senate.
The House might pass something but uh
but the Senate I think is going to be a
bit more squeamish. They have a they
have a higher threshold for pain over
there. uh I mean, excuse me, a lower
threshold for pain. They they feel it,
you know, the House has a higher
threshold. They'll pass bills that are
going to go nowhere. Uh even though
they're very politically damaging, which
it was the case back in 2017 on the
repeal replace that bill that the House
passed. I warned colleagues, the
policyy's bad, the politics are worse.
The bill would never be adopted by the
Senate. Never in a million years. And um
of course, nothing close to the House
bill was even considered in the Senate.
Yeah. Yeah. And you are right. I I talk
to a lot of Congress people and say,
"Oh, we passed all of these bills."
Yeah, but that's obviously not going
anywhere. When you even have Josh Holly
saying that he's not going to sign it.
So, yeah. And and Ryan Rand Paul, I
think, has said he's against the the Oh,
Rand Paul is now my Democratic hero. I
mean, listening to him give floor
speeches about, you know, the Boston Tea
Party and tariffing. I'm I'm all for
Rand Paul right now. Well, he's he's
he's absolutely right on tariffs. Uh,
you know, he's going to be against
reconciliation, not because of the
Medicaid changes because he's he's got
other reasons, but uh but he's certainly
right about the
[Music]
tariffs. In 2017, you told the New
Yorker that the Republican party needs a
reckoning. I would imagine that you
still feel that that's the case going
into whatever 2028 will hold.
There are a lot of conservatives or
center left center right people,
moderates, whatever you want to
self-identify as, who feel like the
Republican project just needs to be left
behind and that there is no point in
trying to resuscitate something that for
all of the values that you just extolled
in the last 15 minutes, you don't see
any of that being represented even by
the folks that you would imagine would
like a Marco Rubio who has had a full
conversion, right to Trumpism. What do
you say to those types, you know, who
are at the bull work now, for instance,
and seem like they're just all in for
the Democrats? Well, I think this this
is where I kind of maybe differ. I mean,
if we want to change the party, we have
to we have to still kind of stay within
it. Uh, and I I I do feel strongly about
that. And frankly, you know, the
Democrats have tremendous opportunities.
Uh, but they're very much tied to their,
you know, organized labor base. And on
an issue like tariffs, they just can't
make the argument because many of them
agree with the the policy, the basic
policy. They don't like the way Trump's
doing it. And I think the Democrats have
have that challenge. And also, you know,
I think we've also seen too where the
Democrats have struggled uh you know,
particularly on the border. It was clear
that the American people, you know, were
were appalled by, you know, the mayhem
at the border during the Biden
administration and they were just too
lacadasical about it for at least the
first three years of their
administration. It didn't get serious.
And it was a it was a very important
issue. People do believe in the nation's
sovereignty and that there should be an
orderly system of entrance and exit and
and the Democrats just weren't able to
speak to it. And I I think also too, you
know, and I think where the Democrats
also get into trouble and which I think
keeping a lot of Republicans away is on
some of these issues where they feel
like a lot of Republicans feel like the
Democrats might be a little too
condescending uh for them. Um they speak
down to them. Like for for example, you
know, and and I'm for transgender's
rights. I think a you know, person
should be able to transition and we
should, you know, respect that. But, you
know, when that situation happened at
the University of Pennsylvania where the
swimmer transitioned from, you know,
male to female, broke all the records,
you know, you know, blew away everybody
at the NCAA's, a lot of people said, you
know, that's unfair. And then they were
called transphobic. And they said,
'Well, no, I'm not transphobic. I just
have a pair of eyes and ears and you
know I think that's unfair and and then
I think there are just too many on the
the left who you know just didn't know
how to respond appropriately to people
who saw things that were that they that
they questioned and without being
ridiculed or told that they're you know
they're a hateful person. And I think
this is where the Democrats have to kind
of stop listening to this this fringe
base of theirs uh and start talking like
normal people uh to uh to folks. And I
think that's keeping a lot of
Republicans away because I think
Democrats have some opportunities like
Republicans for years, you know, I was
one of I was one of the I was well the
last, you know, pro-choice Republican in
the House when I left. There might be a
couple now since DOBS, but uh but who
actually voted against a 20we abortion
ban and I voted, you know, to to fund
Planned Parenthood. I was the only one
there for a while and I I found that you
know, Republicans were not on the right
side of issues like that. That that came
into stark uh relief during the uh you
know their post jobs when you know when
the when Row was overturned then boy oh
boy then all of a sudden the politics of
that issue changed and Republicans
realized that they were on the wrong
side of that issue. the Democrats had an
opportunity, but that's not but that was
not the only issue they had. They they
just haven't been able to speak to the
economic anxieties of people to the
extent uh they they needed to. Like I
said, and you know, during the Biden
administration, there were two Democrats
just did not um you know, take in
inflation seriously enough early early
on. Oh, they said it was transitory when
Larry Summers is out there, you know,
beating the drum telling them it's a
it's it's an enormous problem. They just
didn't do it. And then, you know, I was
one of the folks too when uh during the
the previous race when when it was going
to appear that Biden was going to run
and Trump was going to run and I was
saying at the time, you know, close to
70% of the voters think one candidate is
too old and the other too dangerous.
What part of this aren't the parties
hearing, you know, especially the
Democrats who I remember were they
listening to you? Because it feels as if
you should have been an incredibly
important voice. I I was encouraging no
labels at the time to try to put
together a fusion ticket. And it was
frankly it was the Democrats or these
people aligned with the Democrats who
went apoplelectic. They said they're
going to destroy whoever runs. And and I
would say to them, well, you know, there
were group I think that one group called
Third Way was one of the groups leading
this. And I said, well, you ought to
call two-way because they only wanted
two candidates. I said, you can't on the
one hand argue that democracy is at
risk, that we're going to lose it, and
then do everything you can to undermine
a can candidates from getting on the
ballot. you're trying to, you know, we
need less democracy in order to save
democracy. They said if, you know, if if
there was a third party candidate,
pending candidate, that that would have
elected Trump. And I said, well, one, we
don't know that. Uh, and two, um, you
got a problem with your candidate and
you know what you see in this. and they
didn't want to hear it until of course
that that debate where Biden faltered
badly and then then everybody
recogned the morning after said that you
know Biden needs to go and I got a lot
of hate from a lot of Democrats so we
don't need to hear this that and then
you know three weeks later he was gone
and everybody kind of came to that
position it was a rough three weeks um
yeah if we had more time I would like to
talk to you further about the no labels
issue because it was pretty clear from
the states where a third party candidate
would have had the most effect that it
would have swung it towards Trump and
you even see the impact of RFK Jr.
moving over to the Trump side and Tulsi
Gabbard that it shifted, you know,
mid-level partisans in that direction.
But I want to ask you about 2028. My my
quick view on that though was Yeah. But
they w they weren't looking at states
like Texas and Kansas and others where
the third party candidate might have
harmed Donald Trump uh significantly.
They were only looking at battlegrounds.
Yeah. Well, battlegrounds decided
though. We lost all of those. So anyway,
um what are you thinking about 2028 on
the Democratic side? Do you see anyone
that can satisfy the purple America
lane? I'm sure they have candidates out
there. You know, you know, you you're
hearing about Newsome and Gretchen
Whitmer. Certainly Josh Shapiro in
Pennsylvania would be quite formidable.
Um I know Josh well, you know, um he's a
good man. Uh I I think that those those
three are certainly probably top of
list. You're hearing Wes Moore, of
course, uh in Maryland. They have an
interesting group of candidates. I'm not
so sure Nuomo would be the right one. A
California progressive now. He's trying
to center himself a bit. You know,
Whitmer, I think, has an interesting
profile, though. I know she's gotten
dinged up a little bit over that White
House meeting. Not sure if that's It'll
be fine by then. I think I think so,
too. But, but, you know, I think between
Whitmer and Shapiro and Wes Moore, those
are probably the three that jump out at
me. There may be some others, but those
are the three that are just kind of
striking me as who could be uh inside
inside lane. Of course, now you have to
watch that progressive wing. What does
AOC do? Um, does she does she decide to
jump in? She would be a very formidable
primary candidate, probably a disastrous
general election candidate. Uh, but a
but a formidable formable primary
candidate. Yeah, that's a tough one. And
there'll definitely be a heated
progressive lane and then a heated
moderate lane, though that language
